Moveo

High attrition rates in education can be attributed to many factors and is difficult to quantify. The biggest hurdle in some expert opinions is the inability to relate to what is being taught.

Goal

Design an app that helps build “momentum” in a learner's field of interest. I believe the best form of learning comes from a person's desire and curiosity. The app is designed to nourish that curiosity through self-guided learning, technology channels, and support from the community.

Filtering, identifying, and categorizing ideas

The theme of solving a problem in "Education" was the starting point of exploration. As ideas and words around "Education" surfaced, I was able to merge these isolated words into logical groupings.

Ideas began to crystallize through the mapping and sorting exercises. Identifying possible target audiences, features, technology solutions and just as important are the red flags. In this case, "accreditation" was a major sticking point that needed to be considered.

User Testing and Paper Prototyping

Finding opportunities from user feedback

Here are some captured feedback and responses.

Feedback Options
I don't want to be pressured into commiting to a goal. auto-save, remove commitment button
Is there an option to have more than one area of interest? multiple tasks-list
Is there a way for users to be accredited? accreditation vs self-guided learning
How is the learner task list generated? Manually, suggested by other users, recommendations
Are there any incentives to complete a task? Gamification, awards, sponsored tasks

Designing through research

The word “Momentum” discovered in affinity mapping stood out as a key value that I wanted to convey in this app. Motivation in learning is easily lost when learners cannot relate, and the apps goal is to build a learners interest and sustain “Moveo(momentum)” in learning. After several iterations — Moveo, the latin word for “Momentum” emerged as the winner. Targeting a younger audience, I wanted the wordmark to be modern and versatile for mobile screens. The search ended at Univia Pro.

Adding a little flavour to the logo, I chose to use the italicized style to invoke movement. I also modified the letter "v" to form a “check mark”, as one of the main features of the app is task management.

In Action

Results

User testing helped shape the design and flow of the app. Sometimes, eagerness and time crunches gave me the urge to jump right into high fidelity mockups before the design was flushed out on paper. Is it a bad thing? I found that it can be done at the same time and sometimes it can even save you time. Using UI kits can be more of a hassle if UI elements influence your design decisions and layout.
